text:p.text:span: question marker added to consonant final words

First person plural marker prefixed to verbs stressed on the first syllable of the root in first person dual, trial and plural forms. It is often not marked on the plural exclusive unless something else intervenes between the pronoun he and the verb
He su ayoh vu bë adah vun in ham rë.
We are not able to hide it from you
Let's go and follow my mother's tracks
Alu aluḳ dub loḳ ayed sënë
We two went to school in our own language
cob, core, the central section of a cob of corn or of pandanus fruit after the outer seeds or kernels are removed
Aba neggëp loḳ sakom ayo peggo
There is an inner core inside a cob of corn
They removed the fruit of the pandanus and threw the inner core away.
Pedi sakom abel luu vu sa
He prised off two rows of kernels from the corn cob for me.
pole, the lowest of the three horizontal poles to which a fence is tied and which form the main horizontal framework for the fence. This is the biggest of the three
stik-longpela diwai o mambu ol i yusim bilong pasim banis i go pas long en
They laid the horizontal pole in the fence and tied it in
It is laid out in rows
having a flat tail-as of eels, tadpoles, catfish
stretpela tel-olsem tel bilong maleo, pis, samting
Beggöb raḳ bël rabu raḳ abes
Eels are able to climb waterfalls by using their tails
Meġov abes pepöö ya gevaha los nema raḳ
Tadpoles' tails fall off and they grow legs and hands
Alam dëvaroh go abiba, in nos nivesa
People plant abiba yams because they are good food
kain binatang em i save plai long nait
Ġab ti arë nebë abu balam dëgga
There is a beetle called abu which people eat.
edible wild sugarcane-Saccharum edule; this is the generic term,-many different varieties are grown
The women roasted `pitpit' for the men

A flat sheet used as a rubbish carrier. They are usually used in pairs and are made from any suitable material such as the sago palm trunk, the sheath of a banana palm, or in more recent times from a couple of pieces of flat iron or plywood.
pangal bilong saksak ol meri save kisim bilong bungim pipia long en.
Anii keḳel sengo sengo raḳ abuung ya vud degwa
Anii scraped up the rubbish with the abuung and put it at the foot of the banana palm.
Angans-people of the Angan family of languages, formerly referred to as the Kukukuku people
manmeri Watut inap i go long Asiki
The Angans killed Mr Baum long ago
Maluh seyu anöö raḳ aggis ading.
The man tied the dog up with a long rope.
Nabë sa nanër dus, më ading, og yiḳ yoh vu!
Whether I speak briefly or at length, it doesn't matter.
The water had dried up and I went a very long way.
We are going to a very distant place.
Bööḳ yu ti vare deneruuk raḳ ḳedu sënë medenare ading teka.
A herd of pigs were rooting on this mountain and they were standing at a little distance.
The stream was dried up and (so) he went very far.
Nevu luu nedo vavu ba, nevu adingseḳë.
He had two teeth on top, and they were very long (teeth).
Mala luho sënë selupek yam adingseḳë rot.
These two eyes stuck right out a long way.
Deneripek kap gedëg aën los nġaa pin.
They washed the cup and the iron saucepan and everything else.
Devanuh aën ahë petes ggërin newaj nebë ḳelenavi.
They wore a flat sheet of iron covering their chests like a shield.
There it is! It's coming to you
It's going towards you, so come and get it.
Alam deneḳo agesip beya denetunġ raḳ alam nijraḳsën.
People were taking handkerchiefs and going and putting them on sick people.
The agate stone is a hazy blue colour.
Bööḳ neggëp loḳ agi lom veya meya
The pig was lying here and it ran away
over there, distant from both speaker and hearer
Over there! It's going to fall!
tree with small yellow berries, the seeds of which are cooked and eaten
Sa vesi aġe anon raḳ payëëḳ
I cooked the aġe seeds on a piece of clay pot.
variety of the thick strong bamboo
Apel ti sënë arë nebë aġee bepedus ading
This bamboo is called aġee and has long sections between nodes.
variety of plant used for killing cockroaches
wanpela kain gras bilong kilim kokros
Aġeleng nare pahup ayo los vos degwa
Aġeleng grows in grassland and at the edge of the bush
the central horizontal forked strut of a snare, the part against which the rope or vine holds the victim
spring bilong trap-i save pulim kapul i go pas long en na i dai
The aġo grips the snare tightly (and holds it together).
first son, the first male issue of a woman, regardless of whether the child lives or not
Kwepöḳ ḳo nalu aġuu loḳ huk anon
Kwepöḳ gave birth to her first male child in the garden
Ham gwelë nabë ga sa geving aġuu lu ata.
You will see that it will eat me along with first born son and his mother.
the trunk or stalk of a tree or other plant, the shaft of a spear
They picked the pitpit fruit and left the stalks standing
the central or main part of something, a kind of something
Anutu su tato arë agga ngwë vu hil
God hasn't shown us any other name
He hanġo honġ ġaġek rëḳ yö agga ti
We have heard what you said, but it is a different message
Alam sënë deyam vu mehönon pin, gevu ayej agga ti ti lo pin
These people came from all peoples and from every kind of language
fence materials-the reeds and small trees and other timber used for building a fence
ol pitpit diwai samting bilong wokim banis
Supin agga pin in baḳu heek jaḳ
He collected all the materials to build the fence
Nër nġaa aggagga tato vu bu
She told her grandchild all kinds of things
She was planting all kinds of food
Kaunsor vo huk aggata vu alam in dekesik
The councillor assigned the road work to the people in order that they might cut the grass
I opened the road and came down.
Alam delöö sengii gedegga nos böpata in yiḳ hil bud lo hir aggata nebë sënë
People dance and feast because that was the custom of our forefathers
Sa navo ġaġek raḳ sir benesesor hir aggata
I will speak to them and correct their behaviour
gateway, an entry way on a road or into a garden etc, one that is outside
Alam Damaskus vare deneġin Paulus loḳ aggata avi pin yoh vu buk los ranġah
The Damascans kept watch for Paul day and night at every entry (into the city)
the way or custom of human beings; earthly ways. Usually used in a negative sense as being opposed to spiritual ways or the ways of God
Ham vu dob sënë om ham nesepa loḳ aggata-dob-yi
You are from this world so you follow the ways of the world
the way of life or which leads to eternal life
Aggata sënë og yiḳ yö navi baggata-mala-tumsën-yi.
This road is his own body and it is the way of eternal life.
all along the road, at intervals along the road
long rot i go i go
Niraḳ meneggëp aggatata metöḳ ya begganġ
He was sick all along the road until he finally reached the village
He went and cut yam stakes along the road
rope, vine, string,-the generic term for vine
Amon bun riing raḳ aggis vu huk anon
Amon bound up a bundle of yam stakes with vine in the garden
The men used to wear G-strings in the old days
snare or trap used to catch small animals
Alam devaḳu aggis in degeḳo saġ
People make snares to catch animals
kind of vine. There are two varieties with this name. The vine is thin and somewhat like bamboo in appearance. It is used for tying fences.
rop-i grinpela, kain olsem mambu, bilong pasim banis long en
The aggis-apel vine grows at the lower altitudes.
canes, climbing plants, plants which grow like vines but which are stiff and woody, unsuitable for tying
Aggis-seḳë og yiḳ nġaa vahi sën neggol nebë aggis rëḳ mu ahëseḳë nebë ḳele
Plants are those things which grow like vines but are stiff like trees
bilum bilong pikinini i stap insait long bel na i kamap long taim mama i karim em
The placenta stuck fast (i.e. didn't deliver)
leaf-the short leaves at the top of a banana just before the flower shoot appears
sotpela lip bilong banana i soim olsem em bai karim
Vud tur ahaa dus in ngis anon
The banana sent out its short leaves because it was about to flower
bird of paradise-probably the male Count Raggi's Bird of Paradise
His cousin shot a bird of paradise from a blind
crested bird of paradise-probably the female Count Raggi's Bird of Paradise; said to be the mother of the aheeng
Aheeng-ata niviis su nivesa rot rë
The aheeng-ata doesn't have really brilliant plumage
Guu vev raḳ ahë in höḳ megga
The guava gave him a stomach ache because he picked it green and ate it
Nyël bejuu yi loḳ Meruġii ahë.
The snake twisted itself in Merugii's inside.
Ahë töḳ meyö medo netabuu beya.
His insides came out and he carried them in his arms and went.
Ġëwa nos los anöö lu nġaa pin ahë.
You are eating food with dog and all kinds of animal faeces in it.
waste material from some activitiy such as gardening, building, etc.
Maḳ mehöti nedo sagu om sën nevonġ huk ahë los ḳatimeng ris to.
There must be someone living up there and so he his sending his garden rubbish and cucumber leaves down.
Seya verup mesevev loḳ ġanġ ahë.
I came up and I lit the plank shavings.
lower, down below-in a direction down the valley, further down than where the speaker is
Denare bël vaha ahë Jen Atov.
They stood downstream there at Jen Atov.
Alu nayah menaya in alu he hurmahen lu avëh nedo ahë.
Let's go back because our children and wives are down there.
Hil ahëd kevus los ahëd nalu nedo lok hil ayod
Our large and small intestines are inside us
rubbish left behind when someone moves on
pipia bilong man i slip na kirap i go
Mehöti sën neggëp loḳ sënë bekedi meya gahë aliveng to nedo
This person slept here and left his rubbish behind when he went
having a large stomach, a pot-belly-such as is brought on by drinking beer
Mehö ahë böp om hil nanër nabë ahë biing
We call a person with a big stomach ahë biing
Apel agga ahë dahis, geġanġ ahë petes
A bamboo trunk is cylindrical, and a plank is flat.
standing on edge, tilted over, not straight, crooked
Mehöti sap mudeng sënë rëḳ nevonġ ahë degën
Someone cut this plank but he made it crooked
bottom, base, the part that something rests on
Sa varah ggaġeng ahë degwa raḳ gesa ġelu len.
I turn the drum bottom up and I pierce it (with a sharp instrument) to make a hole.
Mon Nahes vo ggaġeng ahë degwa lob ata mala mir.
Mon Nahes hit her with the base of the drum and his mother's eye closed up.
Dejelë go ahë degwa nedo ya telig in debajanġ la jaḳ na
They laid the bottom yams down on the level area in order to pile others on top
dregs, the little bit of something left at the bottom of a virtually empty container
Ḳo bël ahë degwa besu pup rë
He just got a bit of water in the bottom,- it wasn't full
Ahë veriik raḳ nedo ahë desën
The large intestine sits on the ahë desën
anus, the large intestine . The intestine was washed out and filled with fat and meat like a sausage and cooked
Avëh devo bööḳ reggos loḳ yah bööḳ ahë ġami lob deyeh
The women put the pig flesh into the pig intestine and cooked it.
Ahë ġami tur in niraḳsën ti yö nebë sënë
The intestine comes out because this is a kind of sickness
She fastened a laplap around her
foundation, support-the base of a wall or dam; large stones logs etc forming the base of something; the foundation for the headdress used in dancing.
bikpela, strongpela-ol bikpela ston o diwai ol i putim i go pas bilong strongim sampela samting
Debë ahë ggeneng ya neggëp in degebë nengwah jaḳ gëp doḳ reek len
They laid some foundation logs down to stack the firewood on under the house
Alam dëkeden nengwah og dëbë ahë ggeneng loḳ in ḳoov rëḳ jaḳ ġelönġ
When people split firewood they put a log underneath so the axe doesn't hit a stone
thick-especially of a single sheet of something
bikpela-olsem buk i gat planti pes
The book is a thick one
Depam ayööng loḳ baar bahë ggoh rot
They pumped the ball full of air and it was tight
pipia wantaim spet wara i karim
Bël vaar meḳo ḳele lu nġaa yam behil anër bë ahë gwap
When the river floods and brings down trees and things, we call it ahë gwap.
full up, swollen, bursting-especially of the stomach, pregnant
Avëh naluj loḳ bahëj gweng raḳ
When women are pregnant their stomachs swell
lait bilong san long apinun o moning
The suns rays shone down (through the clouds)
swollen, pregnant, having a swollen stomach which makes one's clothes stick out
Avëh ahë köd in nalu loḳ
The woman's stomach was swollen because she was pregnant
Medo nelë gedelöö sengii lob ahë kod bë na medöö geving
He watched them dancing and he became excited, wanting to join in
kros i pinis, bel i kol
Arig ahë sengën vu sa rëḳ ma gahë kul
My brother was angry with me, but then he calmed down
They chipped away at the plank and made it thin
bikpela bel bilong kakaruk, samting, i gat ston long en
Hil nanër soḳ ahëj ḳevus nebë ahej̈ ḳatëḳ
We call bird stomachs ahëj ḳatëḳ
Aggata ahë ḳaving yoh vu kaar timu noh
The road was narrow, wide enough for only one car
the intestine which is removed and washed clean for eating, also known as ahe veriik
bel bilong pik ol i stretim long kaikai
Avëh dëvër bööḳ ahë veriik medëvonġ ahë laa ya lom dënër sën dega lo bë ahë ḳedik
Women take the intestine out of pigs and clean it out and they say the part they eat is ahë ḳedik
Ahë ḳeḳunġ raḳ in nenum bia
He has a fat stomach from drinking bear
She moulded a ball of clay
One sweetpotato grew round and fat
matted, lumpy, made up of little balls
Alam loo dejegwi barep ahë ḳemu ḳemu
The coastal people make sago balls
Ahë ḳerin in degga bööḳ in
He's angry because they ate the pig without giving him any
Avëhnö ahë ḳerin in yi lob keyëh maluhnö yi begöġ lin.
His sister was angry with him and broke the tongue of his (her brother's) Jaw's harp.
Ahë ḳevus töḳ loḳ ayo in degelu raḳ ruġ
His stomach burst inside him because they speared him
Gga nos benare loḳ ahë ḳevus
He ate and the food was in his stomach
Ahë leeng gesu raḳ aperek rë
He was afraid and wouldn't climb the pandanus palm
Ahë leḳ neruu hil newad vuuḳ los hil ahëd ḳevus
The diaphragn separates our hearts from our stomachs.
selfish, sorry for, not willing to give something up
Kwa vo bë bo go ti vu sa lob ḳo raḳ rëḳ ahë loḳ vu lob bë yah
He thought of giving me a yam and picked it up, but then decided he didn't want to, and put it down again
Vaḳu ḳele ahë maggin ti meneya
He carried a heavy log and went off
Vo ḳöḳrëëh ahë meggeveng vu nalu begga navi veroo
She gave the yolk to her child and ate the white herself
Gga nos ahë meḳus lob tunġ yi
He ate some dry food and choked on it
dry leaves, or grass-bits of dried crumpled leaves or grass
Supin sëh ahë memus in gelu masis doḳ mebev
She collected the bits of dried grass to light a fire
bel i pait, bel i kros
Saġ mejii ahë menġëës om su dëgga ahë rë
The mejii stomach is bitter so they don't eat it.
Nos main yi gekedi meya ahë meyip
He had no food, but got up and went away hungry
Avëh ya deperurin bööḳ ahë nalu in hil besi maġa
The women went and scraped the pig intestines for us to cook and eat
lap nogut tru i go inap bel i pen
He laughed so much his stomach hurt
It's not heavy, it is light
Lë nġaa ti bë su yoh vu rë bahë nipaya
He saw that something was not right and so was unhappy
Nġaa nivesa töḳ vu yi om ahë nivesa
Something good happened to him, so he is happy
bed, sleeping place, the aura that remains in the place where a person who has just left slept
man i slip pinis na i go
Rëḳ doḳ gëp mehöti ahë nudeng lob rëḳ pelë yi rot gesu gëp nivesa rë
He will sleep in another person's bed and he will toss and turn and won't be able to sleep well
happy, excited, exuberant, caught up in the excitement of being part of a crowd, of doing something together as a group
Delë sir mahëj nġaya om delöö rot benyëġ heng
They saw how many of them there were and were so exuberant they danced until morning
Hur mahen delë sir bahëj nġaya in sir
The children saw that there were very many of them together and they were really happy
the part leftover, remnants; the little bit that is left after eating etc
pipia i stap, wan wan i stap
Nos nġahi rot rëḳ degga geyiḳ ahë pahu mu nedo
There was a lot of food but they ate it and only the remnants were left
bloated, pot-bellied, having a swollen stomach
His stomach is distended from drinking (beer)
pelvis. Usually refers to the lower front part of the abdomen and the bones which are cut out in butchering a pig or human, and which are regarded as a delicacy
Hil vaġid peḳooḳ gelu loḳ hil ahëd pepeleng
Our thigh bone fits into our pelvis.
He hit his rear hard on the ground
buttocks, thigh, the rear of the leg
Degga bööḳ ahë pepu loḳ dii ris mala beri
They ate the pig's thigh with fresh green dii leaves
Nabë hil sarömin nos og hil rëk ahëd napuḳ
If we mix up different kinds of food then we will pass wind
fork, notch; the notch or area between forks or branches of a tree
Lah aperek lob to meluḳ ya nedo ahë raġo
He cut the pandanus nut and it fell down and stuck in the fork
Ahëm raḳ in honġ nġaa meġetung kesii in bë mehöti rëḳ gevonġ paya vu
You were worried about your things and hid them so noone would damage/misuse them
Barus kedi meya ahë raru rot
The plane took off and flew into the blue
The weather was fine and so it was hazy
twin, divided, split-as of a tree whose trunk divides into two equal parts
Hurmahen dësero ḳele ahë salaḳ in desemu dabanġ
Children look for forked stick to make catapults
kiau i klostu long bruk na man i kukum bai i gat waitpela samting i stap insait
Hil ġeyeh ḳöḳrëëh ġahis lob nabë dus raḳ napum og reḳ ahë sekwahek veroo
When we cook eggs, if they are close to hatching, then the eggwhite will be white
Avëh ahë sengën in deggodeḳ yi nos
The woman was angry because they stole her food
Kerë ḳele ahë sepëp meyö ggëp metup
He carried the light piece of wood and was running along
stomach noises-to have a grumbling stomach, from hunger, or from eating soft foods
bel i mekim planti nois (em i hangre samting)
Ahë sis yi in maḳ gga nos rumengsën
His stomach is growling because he must have eaten some soft food
Nġaa ahë soveḳ om ayööng nevë
It's light so the wind blew it
a broad open stretch of water
calm, to calm down; quieted, cooled down after being angry
bel i kol, i kisim bel isi
Deggodek yi bööḳ medegga lob ahë sengën rot, rëk denër ġaġek nivesa vesa vu lob ahë to
They stole his pig and ate it, and he was very angry but the spoke nicely to him and he calmed down
to need to go to the toilet
Hurmahen saga ahë to in namëëḳ om ham tato asoreng vu yi
That child needs to go to the toilet so show him where it is

stomach. A kind of second pouch or stomach in some animals, such as the masanġ, jenaa, beḳöġ, in which food, leaves, etc accumulate and are predigested before passing to the stomach proper. This stomach is taken out and cleaned, and then smoked and eaten with salt.
Alam böp dëgga saġ ahë valo sën wirek
The old people used to eat the ahë valo pouch of animals
Avëh detabuu naluj raḳ ahëj veġo
Women nurse their children on their laps
intestine, a long coiling intestine in a pig
Bööḳ ahë veriik yööhu gahë ḳevus yööhu
A pig's large intestine and its stomach are different parts (of its anatomy)
Gga jojeng meris genos ma lob ahë verup rot
He just ate greens without starchy food and got a bad case of diarrhea
Yesu lë yi bahë ving yi
Jesus saw him and loved him
Nabë ahëm geving, og ġeyoh vu bë gwevonġ besa niġ veseek jaḳ
If you want to, then you are able to make me well
Nabë Anutu ahë ving yi yönon, og nam doḳ vu yi.
If God really loves him, then He would come and help him.
cross, angry, wanting to pay someone back for an injury
Sahëġ vonġin sa nġaa besevo loḳ yah nyëvewen
I was cross because of (what you did to) my things, and took revenge
Alam parahek ahëj vonġin alam hir nġaa nivesa bedevenġev sir
Sorcerers covet the good things people have and cast spells on them (the people)
Ahë yes om neḳo nalu pevis pevis
She is amenable so she is always having children
side-the soft part of the side without bone, between the ribs and the hips; waist
wanpela hap bilong banis bilong man-dispela hap nogat bun long en
Mehönon ahëj yes neggëp vuheng loḳ kwebej los bejuj
The soft sides of people's waists lie between their ribs and their hips
Nahub gwetunġ dëg geto ahë yes in beröp
Put the cooking pot down gently lest it break
Soḳ vo newis loḳ ahë-vuuḳ ris om ġebanëh
The bird built its nest among the ahë-vuuk leaves, so shoot it.
place, mark of something which identifies it, or shows where it belongs, or where it has been
the marks or remains of a previous fence
the marks showing how high the sea has come up the beach
an old house or village site
hole-the row of holes which follows the edge of the garden in planting yams
hul bilong yam i stap arere long lain
Varoh sahob los gwee sala yi loḳ ahëbu
He planted sahob and gwee alternately in the holes
spell-a spell spoken over something to make it strong, or to make it happen, e.g. on a dog, on love magic, etc
Mehönon devenġev ahëbu raḳ hir nġaa in bë anon jaḳ
People say spells over their concerns to make them happen (the way they want)

a short piece of palm bark curled into a flattened hollow cylinder and laid on top of the head and tied down with the ggeneng. This is covered with the leḳ and the tönġ goes inside the ahëbu, taking the mid part of the leḳ with it. The whole is then wrapped in cloth and fastened and forms the base to which the headdress itself is attached
wanpela hap kako bilong kangal bilong singsing
Alam dëjoo ggeneng loḳ yuj loḳ mëm dëtunġ ahëbu raḳ ya medëduu ahon
People tie the ggeneng vine in their hair and then they put the ahëbu on top and fasten it
light, sign, indication, a distant light, such as a fire or lamp on the mountain, showing the presence of someone
lait i save sain,-olsem lait bilong lam, o bilong paia long nait, samting
Delë nengwah ahëggi ggëp huk anon
They saw the light of the fire in the garden
salty, stinging, a biting or stinging sensation, the sensation in the throat caused by salt or aerated drinks.
The sun is very hot (i.e. it causes a stinging sensation)
The salt made the food salty
Wain ahëggin nedo loḳ ġabum ti, lom deḳo gedevo ya verup loḳ avi.
There was sour wine in the dish and they took it and put itup to his mouth.
grass, garden rubbish, grass or earth heaped on a fence to protect it from the weather
gras ol i save karamapim banis long en bilong ren i no ken bagarapim em
Detunġ heek ahësa raḳ bööḳ gedevesi
They put rubbish from the fence on the pig and burned it (to singe the hair off)
Depip bëḳ gedetë ahësa ya vu ḳöḳrëëh
They squeezed the grated coconut and threw the residue to the chickens
discarded material of various kinds, as leached sago pith, scraped coconut after the cream has been squeezed out, shavings from planing timber, etc
pipia-samting yu save kaikai o kisim gutpela bilong en na pipia bilong en yu save tromwe
The sun shone on the vine and made it stiff/brittle
Su ġenanër ġaġek ahëseḳë vu alam vahi geġenanër ġaġek ahë yes vu honġ alam.
Don't speak harshly to other people and gently to your own people
Mehö sënë nevonġ ahëta menegga nos rot
This person is gluttonous, and eats a great deal of food
Mehö ahëta los nenum wain panġsën
A gluttonous person and one who drinks a lot of wine
naked; with the lower parts of the anatomy visible
Vuu tob loḳ nemaj geveya meya ahëtöḳsën
He left his laplap in their hands and fled naked
Memö la denedo loḳ mehö sënë meyö medo neya ahëtöḳsën yö wirek la.
Some demons were in this person and he had been going around naked for a long time.
police-this was the term used in the early days for the Papua New Guinean police. It arose from the practice of the police wearing very short tight laplaps
Nër vu yi ahëvavu bedetunġ Pita luḳ ya ḳarabus
He told his police and they put Peter in gaol
Ahëvavu vanëh adiiv losho yi alam pin-ë medediiḳ ya veröḳ yi.
The policeshot the Angan and all his people and they died completely.
Re yoh vu bë bo hil vër in Kerisi ahëvingsën sënë?
Who is able to remove us from this love of Christ?
In ahëvingsën su rëḳ nama na rë, gaḳ yö rëḳ gëp degwata!
Because love will not disappear, it will remain forever!
Aggis nyëës ahë wëëk om dejengö doḳ apel dun loḳ mëm ahë yes jaḳ
The nyëës vine is stiff, so they put it into a new bamboo and then it becomes soft
Sa nanër malu anam, og alu rëḳ dadii aggis ahëwëëk manom.
I will tell him that we should come, then we will pull on the tightened rope and come back
He stuck a cockatoo crest into his hair
He made it secure/held it down with a stone
Su ġenaduu ahon rë, gaḳ gëp talet
Don't fasten it tight, leave it loose
rope which is plaited or twisted
baklain, pislain, rop ol i save wokim long han-olsem pislain samting
Bun nengwah raḳ ahov in aggis vepul
He tied the bundle of firewood with a rope because the vine broke
There is only a bit in the bottom (it's not full)
I pulap hap tasol na i no pulap tru
Nevu luu mu nedo ahu, geluu nedo vavu.
He had two teeth down below, and two on top.
The ones from downstream came up
down there-distant from the speaker and the hearer
Go down there and then come back
Ya verup, lob ahugu dëdo loḳ aggata.
She came up, and the people from down there were sitting in the road.
downward-in a downward direction, at a place lower than
Mapos hir dob to meya ahuyi meya.
The ground belonging to Mapos goes down there and keeps going.
down-on the lower side of; at a place lower down
The fence down there is finished
down there-away from both speaker and hearer on the lower side
Huk anon neggëp dus vu huk ta ahuyigu
The garden is close to the old garden down there
abdomen-the soft part of the abdomen around the navel and between the navel and the groin
Hil aidamba neggëp dus vu hil verod vahi ahu
Our abdomen lies close to the navel on the lower side
The ajee fruit has fallen down and is finished.
Alam dëvong begganġ seḳë raḳ ḳele ajee, in suveḳ su neloḳ rë
People use the ajee tree for the framework of their houses because the borers don't attack it.
a kind of tree used in house building
kala bilong ol abus olsem pik na arapela abus tu, kain kain kala olsem blak, wait, ret
Bööḳ ajel ti luḳ huk begga nos
A tawny coloured pig got into the garden and ate the food
dark grey possum with a white chest
wanpela kain kapul-i gat blakpela gras long beksait na wait long bros bilong en
type of reed used for arrow shafts
wanpela kain pitpit bilong wokim spia
Netunġ rahev loḳ aḳohek in banëh soḳ jaḳ
He put the arrow point into the aḳohek shaft in order to shoot birds
master, owner-one who owns or takes care of something or someone
papa bilong ol samting, man i stap het long ol arapela
The dog's owner/master went and left the dog standing there
Ala nër vu bë kesik nyëġ
His boss told him to cut the grass
expert, someone who excels at something
a person who plays a lot/ a clown
spouse of one's spouse's sibling-the husband of one's wife's sister, or the wife of one's husband's brother
poroman-tupela man i maritim tupela meri long wanpela mama, na tupela meri i maritim tupela man i gat wanpela mama i ken kolim dispela nem long arapela arapela
Alam ngwë in melu ḳo avëh sënë luho ari
He is your ala ngwë because you married sisters.
Saḳ su alam ngwë sa rë
I am not your ala ngwë
Avëh ti ḳo nġaa reggu nivesa loḳ buayo ġelönġ veroo alabasta
A woman brought some nice smelling substance in a white stone bottle made of alabaster
people-this term refers to people who are part of ones own group, i.e. those in a recognizable relationship to oneself
The people have gone to the gardens and the village is deserted
Hil alam deyam vu nyëġ ading
Our people came from a distant place
Mehö sënë yi alam dëdo Aiyura
This person's people live at Aiyura
timid people, lethargic people, people not easily aroused
Alam beböġeksën sën su dëvonġ huk newa newa rë
These lethargic people don't work quickly
Ham su nanër ġaġek meris meris mu nabë alam dahis.
Don't just babble on like the heathen.
Alam hib hir ġebum wirek hen nebë saga.
That was a custom of the old people in earlier times.
ol man bilong bipo yumi kamap long ol
Wirek alam hib degelu raḳ asub
In earlier times our forefathers pierced it with a black palm spear/stake
audience, spectators, people not taking part in the action,-those who just sit around and watch
The spectators were watching the dancing

distributors, callers, those who call out the recipients of each heap of food at a feast. They go from heap to heap calling out in a chanting falsetto who is to receive each pile. At appropriate times, they oversee the distribution of other things such as money or goods
Alam sepoh og yiḳ alam sën denetunġ nos ggelek mehönon
Alam sepoh are the people who distribute food to people
Sa bë nanër niröp vu ham nabë hil alam teta wirek hen diiḳ ggovek ya bedelev
I want to tell you clearly that our leaders from before have died and been buried
Alam teta deloḳ alam ahëj bedetahi ya vu Pilatus bë dëëin Barabas bër vu sir.
The elders persuaded the people and they called out to Pilate to release Barabas to them.
robbers, people who kill someone, hide the body, and carry on normally
man i save paitim yumi na stilim ol samting bilong yumi, raskol
Alam-beġö-hodeḳ la detöḳ raḳ yi loḳ aggata lob desis yi bedus raḳ bë nadiiḳ.
Some robbers found him on the road and they hit him and nearly killed him.
Ham vo yi loḳ ya alam-beġö-yi nemaj
You gave him over into the hands of the soldiers
strangers, foreigners; people from another village
Ġeyam ġenedo sënë ving alam-begganġ-ngwë sën honġ duġin sir lo.
You have come and are living with strangers whom you do not know.
headwater people-the people from the villages beyond Wij: Rarii, Vewev, Gaje, Beyang Kehun, Ayeyök, Mabub, Monaggee, Vahöö, Bewë, etc
Alam-bël-mala og yiḳ hir nyëġ nedo bël mala
The headwaters people are those who live in the headwaters area
Alam deripek bël ggovek medesepa loḳ Yesu om detu alam bël yi
People who are baptised and follow Jesus become Christians
Yesu losho alam-deneḳo-takës lo denegga nos loḳ ti
False prophets will arise and deceive people
Alam sën denesis alam-denenër-ġaġek-ranġahsën bedediiḳ lo hir mewis ham
You are the descendants of those who killed the prophets
dead people, the dead; sometimes used to refer to the spiritually dead
Alam Sadukai denenër bë alam-diiḳsën og su rëḳ dekedi jaḳ nah rë.
The Saducees say that the dead do not rise again.
Alam lo denġo ġaġek bë alam-diiḳsën dekedi jaḳ nah vu bedub, lob vahi denöp raḳ yi.
People heard the message that the dead will rise up again from the grave, and some of them laughed at him.
human beings, people; used to contrast with spiritual people or people who are seeking to follow God's way
Ham su sepa doḳ nġaa sën alam-dob-yi denevonġ lo
Do not imitate the things that the people of this earth do.
Rëḳ gërin alam-ġaġek-keyëhsën ayoj bedesepa doḳ alam-yohvu kwaj nivesa.
Afterwards he will turn the insides of rebellious people and they will follow the good thoughts of righteous people.
Om ham gwelë alam-ġaġek-kuungsën hir huk, beham jaḳ nij nabë saga.
So look at the work false prophets do, and you will recognise them by that.
truthful people, ones who can be believed
Hil natu alam-ġaġek-niröp-yi los nanër ġaġek anon mu.
We should become truthful people and only speak the truth.
Yaġ mahen luu nedo meris yam nġaggee nenga galam-ġël-yi deluḳ medeneripek leḳ.
There were two small boats on their own by the edge of the lake and the fishermen had come down and were washing their nets.
Alam pin sën demuġin medeyam lo, og sir alam-hodeḳ-ata los beġö-yi.
All the people who came first, they are thieves and robbers.
tisa bilong lo, saveman bilong lo
sailors, crew; people who work in boats
Alam-huk-yaġ denetee loo niwëëk ata in bë denatöḳ jaḳ roneḳ.
The sailors paddled really hard in order that they might reach land.
Yesu nër ġaġek peggirinsën raḳ alam-huk-yi nivesa los nipaya.
Jesus told a parable about good workers and bad.
people who pull back, withdraw, shrink back; those who do not persist in a task
Rëḳ mu hil su alam-julsën-yi sën hil rëḳ malad nama lo rë.
But we are not people who shrink back and disappear.
the poor, people who have no possessions
Alam-ḳupeḳ-masën rëḳ demedo geving ham gesu rëḳ nama na rë.
Poor people will always be with you and won't disappear.
ol man i gat planti samting
Debuu aggis niggin ggin tahu alam-los-bengöj hir madub gedetunġ raḳ yu.
They made a circle of thorny vines to imitate a king's headband and they put it on his head.
rich people; people who have lots of possessions, or have a reputation of being wealthy
ol lain i gat planti samting
Alam-los-bengöj-ggoreksën denedeġinengin ham medenevo maggin vu ham.
The rich oppress you and lay burdens on you.
wealthy people; those reputed to have lots of money
Yaġ alaj lo detu alam-los-bengöj-monë-ggoreksën raḳ nyëġ böp sënë yi monë.
The ship owners have become rich by the money of this big city.
people known for their strong faith
Anutu ggooin sir raḳ in bë denatu alam-los-bengöj-vonġvingsën-yi.
God chose them to become people of faith.
people who are clever or wise
Mehöböp raḳ alam-los-kwaj-böp kwaj ni nebë nġaa meris.
The Lord knows that the thoughts of wise men are insignificant.
Anutu ggooin yi raḳ in bë genġo alam-malaj-vesa los alam-diiḳsën pin hir ġaġek.
God chose him to judge the living and the dead.
Debë ḳanaḳ ti raḳ alam-meris nemaj vesa ma dabaj.
They made a mark on the right hands or the foreheads of the insignificant people.
headwaters people-the people of the headwater dialect, starting with the village of Wij
Alam nën og dëdo bël mala
The alam-nën live in the headwaters ofthe river.
Yesu medo negga nos ving alam-nijpaya nġahiseḳë.
Jesus made a habit of eating with many sinners.
Ham nedo dob sënë nebë ham alam-nyëġ-ngwë los alam vatëveḳ mu.
You live on this earth as foreigners and visitors.
Sa bë nanër ġaġek doḳ ayej geġaġek doḳ alam-nyëġ-ngwë ayej nök gëp, in su rëḳ dejaḳ ni rë.
I want to speak in their language and avoid a foreign language, because they won't understand it.
people of the day, of the light
Hil alam-ranġah-yi om hil su nanum meḳeyevin.
We are people of the light, therefore we should not get drunk.
healer, medicine man-people who carried out the healing ritual
man bilong rausim samting long sikman
Alam-rob og yiḳ sir sën denevo yeseḳ los ġelönġ lu nġaa vër in mehönon nijraḳsën lo
Alam-rob are people who take ginger and stones and things out of sick people
Vu wirek sën alam-sën-deseggi-ġaġek medeneġin Israel lo og Betlehem ti nedo barë nebë Elimelek.
Long ago, when the judges governed Israel, there lived a Bethlehem man called Elimelek.
Mehönon Nalu rëḳ gevonġ yi angër na dengupin alam nij paya pin sën depelëpin alam-vonġvingsën-yi lo
The Son of Man will send his angels to gather the bad people who tempted the believers.
Rëḳ alam-yaġ-yi hir ggev ti töḳ vu yi beggee vu yi.
But a leader of the sailors found him and shook him.
Sa su yam in bë tahi alam-yohvu rë.
I didn't come to call righteous people.
Gentiles, people of another kind or group
Honġ mewis ya denedo alam-yu-ngwë hir dob.
Your ancestors went and lived in another people's country.
Ham nġo raḳ ni bë horek nërin he alam Yuda bë he su ayoh vu bë ana medo geving alam-yu-ngwë, ma ana vatëveḳ vu sir rë.
You know that the law forbids us Jews from staying with other people, or visiting them.
Debë ḳanaḳ ti raḳ alam yuj-ading pin nemaj vesa ma dabaj.
They put a mark on the right hands or the foreheads of all the important people.
sorcerers, people in contact with or able to contact spirits; channels
Alam sënë denevonġ ayej vu ġaġek anon nebë sën alam-yuj-töḳsën luu devonġ ayej vu Moses yi ġaġek wirek lo.
These people were speaking against the truth like the two sorcerers spoke against Moses words before.
shortened form of the combination we two will go
Let's go and buy food at the market
shortened form of combination we two went
We went and bought food at the market earlier
The alee frog is sitting on the side of the stone.
tree used for planks, rafters, yam stakes, etc
wanpela kain diwai bilong wokim plang na stik yam
The alen is a very strong tree.
dry leaves used for wrapping food to protect it while travelling, especially the leaves used to line the string bag used for carrying the seed yams to plant
drai lip-ol i save pulimapim dispela i go arere long bilum bilong i no ken skrapim skin bilong yam na arapela samting
Aliveng sën dëlivin nos in bë su navi gerureḳ
They wrap food in dry leaves so the skin won't rub off
meri man bilong en i dai pinis
Her husband died and she remains a widow
Alu hevonġin bë sepa honġ balöö anah mana vu honġ alam.
We want to follow you and the three of us will go back to your people.
Keröḳ vonġ alöö lob alöö nahëp begganġ.
We three caught a cold and so we stayed at home.
variety of edible fungus which grows on trees
Aluheng og ḳedik nivesa ti sën hil aġa
The aluheng is a good fungus which we eat.
man meri bilong en i dai pinis
His wife died and he became a widower
widower--one who remains unmarried after the death of his wife.
man meri bilong en i dai pinis
He has no wife but remained a widower
we two, including the hearer; first person dual pronoun.
The dog barked at us two in the night
Nyël ti töḳ vu aluu ggëp aggata beto meya vos ayo
A snake met us on the road and it went down into the bush
father. This is a classificatory kin term, and includes one's father's brothers, and the fathers of one's siblings
Nër vu ama bë nakud yi
She asked her father to carry her
Vo ama yam mesa hetur brëm!
Give me the hammer and I'll pull out the nail!
second son, the second male issue of a woman
Alam denegga ana nalu in nivesa
People eat turtle eggs because they are good
edible tuber similar to the yam
Anahek og ḳele ti hil aġa anon log anahek og ḳevileḳ ti arë ving
Anahek is a tree whose fruit we eat and it is also a kind of wild yam.
variety of tree-this is a coastal tree and has delicious edible nuts
The anahek nut has delicious juice
second daughter, the second female issue of a woman. When used in conjunction with a name, it is usually shortened to ni, as for example NiĠu
Avëh sënë ḳo nalu mewing lu anii
This woman bore her first and second daughters
to be good at fighting with spears and dodging other people's spears by dancing up and down with the spear arm drawn back ready to throw, while taunting the enemy and dodging
man bilong abrusim spia we narapela man i sut long en na pait long spia
Mapos went to fight at Siiahë
Sakom anon loḳ om hil aġa
There is fruit on the corn so let's eat it
It has two nuts/pieces of fruit on it
Hil anod nedo vesa in hil naha nos meneġadu hil
Our bodies stay alive because we eat food and that strengthens us
Nġaa pin sënë anon raḳ yoh vu ġaġek sën Mehöböp nër lo
All these things happened according to what the Lord said
Ham kwamin nevo ġaġek sën senër agi lo bë anon ma
You think that what I just said is not true!
spirit, essence, reality-this part of a person may leave the body in a dream (cf also kenu)
spirit/ tewel em i lusim bodi long nait long driman
Yesu nġeeḳ böpata ggökin log lëëin anon ya
Jesus cried out loudly and released his spirit
Wirek senër bë sëḳ baġo bööḳ lob gwëbeng sa hevonġ banon raḳ
I said before that I would buy a pig and today I have done it
Anon Vabuung nedo loḳ hil ayod
The Holy Spirit lives within us
Sa ġevonġ Anon Vabuung yi semusën vu ham in bo niwëëk vu ham
I will send the blessing of the Holy spirit to you to strengthen you
variety of tree the bark of which was used for making blankets in times past
wanpela kain diwai ol i save wokim blanket long skin bilong en
Hil bud lo dëtul anon-avuuk navi netu tob wirek
In earlier times our grandparents beat anon-avuuk bark to make clothing.
Rub pork fat on the dog (to make it a good pig hunter)
flycatcher-a variety of plant with a cup at the end of the leaf in which water and insects collect
wanpela kain plaua bilong ples kunai
Anöö-lin og yik sesik ti arë sën nedo nyëġ pahup
The anöö-lin is a the name of a flower which grows in grassland
liklik diwai i gat gutpela plaua
Anöö-nenga og ḳele teka sën nare pahup ayo
The anöö-nenga is a bush that grows in the grassland.
a variety of fungus found growing on dry trees
She ate the greens with anöö-nenga-ris
variety of vine which has an evil smell
wanpela kain rop bilong bus i gat smell nogut olsem pekpek bilong dok
Anööhë yiḳ aggis ti sën nivë
Anööhë is a kind of vine.which has a bad smell
wanpela kain liklik kapul i wankain olsem dok
The anöösik bit the chicken's neck.
Anutu tunġ dob los yaġek genġaa pin
God created the ground and the heavens and everything
Alam sën denedudeḳ vu anutu-kuungsën lo og su rëḳ degeḳo semusemu vu honġ rë.
People who bow down to false gods will not receive any blessings from you.
Bedub avi tateḳin yi gAnutu-yi-alam sën dediiḳ ggovek lo nġahiseḳë vesaj loḳ
The mouths of graves opened and many of God's people who had already died came alive.
Ham nah bekwamin bo ġaġek sën neggëp loḳ Anutu-yi-ḳapiya lo degwa rë.
You go back and think about the meaning of the message which is in the Scriptures.
Nër Bengö Nivesa raḳ Anutu-yi-nyëġ, gevonġ balam hir niraḳsën aggagga pin nivesa raḳ.
He spoke the good news about God's kingdom, and healed people of all kinds of sickness.
The women stuff angahek into lengths of bamboo to cook.
Angër ti vu yaġek meluḳ yam tetolin ġelönġ vër in waaḳ avi
An angel from heaven came down and rolled the stone away from the mouth of the cave
We put food into (lengths of) bamboo (to cook)
alam dërengö nos loḳ apel-ḳöḳ gedëbë abel heek yi raḳ
People put food into apel-ḳöḳ to cook and they make the main horizontal pole of the fence from it
alam dërengö nos loḳ apel-ṿeriik gedëbë abel heek yi raḳ
People put food into apel-veriik to cook and they make the main horizontal pole of the fence from it
the kind of pandanus which bears large clusters of edible nuts
The pandanus produced fruit on all its branches
One of the kinds of skink is called aperek-agga
arrow with a full blade made from bamboo; used for pigs, men, and large game
bunara spia bilong sutim pik, kapul, na man tu
Vanëh ḳöḳrëëh raḳ apop in vaḳë go
He shot the chicken with an arrow because it was scratching in the yams
gable, the ends of a house stretching from the bottom up through the gable to the roof
Hil nanër begganġ nyë vewen vewen nabë arahek
We call the gables at each end of a house arehek
ples nogut i no gat rot
It's a steep cliff with no track
She fell over the cliff and died
ples nogut i go daun tru
Hurmahen vës areeng maluh lob sis yi mediiḳ
The child fell over the high cliff and was killed
He said his name was Kanak
namesake, a person having the same name
Arë ngwë in luho depiv ggev ti
He's his arë ngwë because they both have the same name.
Hil natevin buk gwëbeng, neheng, duu, natuti,...arë-pesiv, geyöḳo
We count the days today, tomorrow, the next day, the one after that,...the fifth day, and the sixth day
Hil arëd-rahu ggëp neggee in hil naha nos raḳ
Our jaws move when we eat
look out!, take care!, exclamation of caution
Watch out! Look out for the dog!
Arë'. Su ġena saga in rëḳ ġebës
Look out! Don't go there or you'll fall!
Sibling of the same sex--a term used in the context of the extended family and so includes the same sex children of ones classificatory fathers
Saggen varah ari ti ti loḳ ganon nġahiseḳë
The pandanus had only a few fruitless sections, there were lots of nuts
sister-in-law, wife of brother, sister of wife, spouse of a cousin
tambu meri bilong man i maritim brata bilong en
The second brother wronged his brother's wife
brother-in-law, brother of husband, husband of sister, spouse of cousin
tambu man bilong meri i maritim brata bilong en
Ari-maluh sën ari lu ġadë reggaj luho
Ari-maluh is the husband of a woman's sister or cousin
pilgrim, wanderer-usually in connection with birds, as some birds are said to sleep somewhere for a night and then move on somewhere else the next day without having any real home
The bird keeps moving around (without a home)
Ġëwëp meġëko loḳ nyëġ nebë soḳ ariv
You keep travelling around all the time like a bird without a home
I'll sleep here tonight (and then go)
He is laying rafters on (the roof of) the house
Smoke is drifting through the trees
tree sp. the bark of which was used for making blankets and cloth. It was also used as a protective turban when fighting. The cloth was made by eating the inner bark of the tree.
diwai ol man bilong bipo i save wokim blanket o laplap long skin bilong en
Alam böp dëkehe aseeng navi medëtul in debengë
People used to peel the bark from the aseeng tree and pound it so they could wrap it around themselves
Bun yu loḳ aseeng in na beġö
He wrapped his head with aseeng cloth because he is going off to fight.
large hole, rubbish hole, a hole dug by humans, not a natural one
I'll dig a hole for pigs (to fall into)
Nġaa pin sën hil naha lo neloḳ ya hil avid beya nare loḳ hil ahëd ḳevus, loḳ tum to neluḳ ya asoreng.
Everything we eat goes into our mouths and goes into our stomachs and finally goes down into the toilet
Ġeḳo sa yom verup in asoreng gesa malaġ tum yah.
You brought me back up from the grave and I am alive again
well; a hole for water; cistern
Hil ḳenud Yakop vo asoreng-bël-yi ti sënë vu he behe nanum.
Our ancestor Jacob gave this well to us and we drink from it.
blackpalm,--used for flooring, making handles for axes , spears, etc
kain limbum bilong wokim plua, handel bilong tamiok samting
They cut the asub for the house
mother-a classificatory kin term which includes one's natural mother, but also the sisters of one's parents, and the mothers of ones classificatory siblings
His mother went but his father stayed
very, very much, very many, extremely, intensely, large-used as an intensifier
Ya devetii bël ata in dengis beggöb
They went and dammed the main river in order to catch eels
orphans, having noone to look after one
Hurmahen ata masën sën ata lu ama dediiḳ gehen alam ma geyö timu nedo
An orphan is a child whose mother and father have died and with no relatives and he is left alone
They cooked the pig liver in a pot
Old people walk with a stick
Hil atov jaḳ og hil rëḳ nadiiḳ
When we become old we will die
alam atov og nij wëëk maya
The people are old so their strength is gone
something flat e.g. a banana leaf or something similar, used for sitting on, or for putting food on
Cut some leaves and we will spread them out (on the ground to sit on)
go down, subside, become small, few in number
Avan raḳ om vonġin nama na
It's subsided so it is just about over
Deḳo bisket ya rot lob avan raḳ
They have really taken the biscuits and they are almost finished
Bother!; exclamation of irritation or impatience
Ave! Sa nedo sënë rot i va ke! Ko sena jaḳ-o!
Bother! Why am I waiting here all this time! I might as well just go!
alas, pity me, exclamation of woe or distress
Oh dear! I've cut my hand
My leg is painful, poor me!
Goodness me!, exclamation of surprise or concern
woman, the female of humans or animals
Deggooin avëh raḳ in jaḳ vu maluh
They selected a woman to marry the man
a classificatory term applied to roundish objects
Sa baġo ḳapis avëh ggëp maket
I bought a round cabbage at the market
lecher-a woman who desires the opposite sex all the time
meri i save holim man nabaut olsem dok
The amorous woman casts eyes at the men
a young unmarried woman who has reached puberty, but is not married yet, or a young wife who has not yet borne a child
Nër yönon rot vu avëh-avö sënë getato nema ya vavunë
He swore to the girl, calling on heaven to witness
Deḳo yu loḳ ġabum ti beyam devo vu avëh-avö sënë.
They brought the head on a plate and came and gave it to this young girl.
a prostitute or immoral woman; one who commits adultery
Avëh-baggëb Rahap neġin mehö luu sën Yosua vonġ beluho deya ḳasöm medenelë Yeriko lo nivesa
The prostitute Rahap looked after well the two men Joshua sent to spy out Jericho.
unmarried woman-usually of someone who is past marriageable age
skelmeri, meri i no gat man
Avëh saga nedo rot geregga ma, om hil nanër yi nabë avëh-bu
That woman has lived a long time without being married, so we call her avëh-bu
queen; an important or famous woman
Avëh-los-bengö vu dob nyë sën sanġ-neverup lo rëḳ kedi bare menanër ġaġek jaḳ alam vu buk sënë nabë denevonġ nġaa nipaya.
The queen of the land to the south will stand up and accuse the people of these days saying they did wrong.
ston i stap long hul long graun na i save hangamap long narapela ston
Avëh-rohek yiḳ ġelönġ sën nesoo luḳ lo
A stalactite is a stone which hangs down
kind of vine used for making fences
wanpela kain rop bilong pasim banis
Avëh-vahus og yiḳ aggis heek yi ti balam dëvaḳu heek raḳ
Avëh-vahus is a kind of vine for fences and people tie fences with it
a Gentile woman; a woman of another group or race
Loḳ avëh-yu-ngwë ti vu sagu nġo bë Yesu nedo, lom ya vu yi pevis.
But a non-Jewish woman who was at that place heard that Jesus was there, and quickly went to him.
sister of a male. This is a classificatory term, so it includes female children of one's classificatory fathers
Avëhnö luho devonġ ġaġek ya vu Yesu
His two sisters sent a message to Jesus
He wiped paint on his mouth
Hil ġeyeh dëg avi in rasap jaḳ menanöḳ
Let's close the top of the saucepan so the steam will rise and cook the food
Peḳa dëġ avi raḳ ya anon
She put the lid on the saucepan
Avi maggin om nġo hil ayed rëḳ su yoh vu bë bengwënġ rë
His mouth is heavy so that he hears our language but can't speak it
to speak bad things; bad mouthed
Nër ġaġek nipaya raḳ alam om sën denër bë avi nipaya
He abused people so they said he had a bad mouth
to make a raspberry, to make a popping or trilling noise with the mouth
She made a derisive sound at him with her mouth
tok i kamap long maus bilong en yet
Avi raḳ menër bë, "Hil angis bööḳ."
He spoke up and said, "Let's kill the pig."
Avi sepëp om vengwënġ hil ayed pevis
His mouth is light so he learned to speak our language quickly
Delëk bavij töḳ in yi ġaġek
They were really amazed at his words
sulk, pout, refuse to talk, to be unsmiling, sober-faced
Avi vuuḳ in maḳ ahë sengën ma va?
He's sulking because maybe he is angry?
Pesuv avi-ḳos in bööḳ ahë nivë
He spat because of the bad smell of the pig dung
Detë bööḳ avi-rahu vu anöö lob medo neköö
They threw the pig jaw to the dog and he was chewing on it
vine used for fences; the sap of another variety is used for medicine
Avi-ruḳ yiḳ aggis ti bedenevaḳu heek raḳ
Avi-ruḳ is a kind of vine and they use it to make fences
garulous, a person who talks incessantly
maus wara, man bilong toktok tumas
He is a garulous person and talks a lot
soft-spoken, gentle, not speaking forcefully so that people will pay attention
Su nër ġaġek los ahëseḳë rë, gaḳ avi-tömeng
He didn't speak harshly, he spoke gently
a variety of freshwater fish with large scales
wanpela kain grile pis long wara
a young woman of marriageable age, i.e. one who has reached puberty but has not married, or at least has not yet borne a child. This term usually occurs in conjunction with avëh
Avö om rëḳ jaḳ maluh ti
She is past puberty so she will soon be married
the final stanza of the vocal part of a dance to indicate that the dancers will be able to rest;the drum roll at the end of a dance
That's the last stanza so they will have a rest
Sing the tail end of the song
a time, a batch or a unit of some kind
Avu ti geving log mëm hil ana
One more time and then we'll go
It's happened twice and it's finished
many times, in groups or units of some kind
Don't go haphazardly (i.e. Don't straggle along in groups, go all together).
He came quickly and arrived at the village
He brought it once and went back
conch shell-blown to announce meetings and to call people together; by extension, any wind instrument
Blow the conch shell to call the people to church
the largest of the four sizes of drum used in dancing
He used to dance to the avuuk-atov
a variety of small flying insect which comes in swarms. They are eaten with abuhek and also with greens
wanpela kain binatang i save plai
Alam Mapos avëh dërengö ġab avuuḳ-lu-ggaġeng ving abuhek gejojeng loḳ apel in reggu nivesa
Mapos women put avuuḳ-lu-ggaġeng into bamboo and cook it with abuhek and greens because it has a delicious smell
wanpela kain binatang i gat planti han
Avuuḳ-lu-ggaġeng yiḳ ġab ti ni nebë ġahiveng rëḳ mahen mu
Avuuḳ-lu-ggaġeng is a kind of insect like a centipede only small
His voice came from over there
Hil su ayed raḳ raḳ rë
Let's stop chattering (so we can hear what is being said)
Nër aye vu sa rëḳ sa duġin
He spoke to me in his language, but I didn't understand it
Nër aye vu sa rëḳ sa su hanġo rë
He told me what he wanted, but I didn't hear him (because I didn't want to do it)
repeat, speak continually, harp, to be always talking about something or some topic or person
Alam pin vu dob dejom raḳ bayej neloḳ Anutu arë
Everyone who prays prays using God's name
Mehö saga aye semusën om nesemu alam pin
Tha person always speaks pleasantly so he is a blessing to everyone
cover-usually a cover placed over the top of pots when cooking food, most often made of banana leaves
Detë ayeheng ya in nos in dejuu
They threw the covering of the pot off so they could serve the food
Hil neheyeh dëg avi raḳ ayeheng
We cover the tops of saucepans with ayeheng
Mumeng people-this term covers people from the lower end of the Snake River valley, and the lower Watut, those that used to be called Patep, Zenag, and Namba tu Buang
Alam böp dënër alam Mumeng bë Ayehu
People used to call people from the Mumeng area Ayehu
variety of sugarcane originally brought from the Ayehu area
kain suga i kam long hap bilong ol Ayehu
Löv sën arë soġek wirek bë buvaha, rëḳ delah ggej arë vun medeḳanġë bë ayehu in buvaha yam vu Ayehu
The real name of this sugarcane used to be buvaha, but they hid their in-law's names and they substituted ayehu because it came from Ayehu
Saga su yoh vu sayoġ rë
That doesn't sit well with me (it upsets me)
over there-beyond the mountain or ridge, out of sight
Go over there to the other side of the ridge
Ayo bebov in bë nanum bël
He is thirsty for a drink of water
without a hole, not hollow, complete, closed off, in one piece
Rëḳ yi röpröp ading nahën neggëp, rëḳ devasu los ayo dahis vu kwa beya meto vaha.
But there was still his long garment, but it was woven in one piece from the neck to the lower leg.
Nabë Anutu kwa nevo bë gevonġ bemehöti ayo-dahis jaḳ, og rëḳ gevonġ bayo dahis jaḳ.
If God decides to harden someone's heart, then he will harden it.
Sayoġ jeġuu in su devo nos sagu ggelek niröp rë
I am upset because they didn't distribute the food right
dished-not flat, deep enough so food won't spill
Hil naha toos loḳ prë nyë ranġah gehil nanum sup loḳ prë ayo ḳanum
We eat toast on a flat plate and drink soup from a dished one
Prë ayo-ḳanum og nos su rëḳ keseh rë
The plate is dished, so the food won't spill
Denër bë geḳo ḳapiya na Mumeng vu kiap rëḳ ayo luu luu bë maḳ ma gemedo ma va
They said he should take the letter to Mumeng to the government officer but he was undecided thinking perhaps he ought to stay
Ayo maggin in ġaġek ti vonġ paya vu yi
He was unhappy because what was said upset him
Begganġ ayo medeḳ, mehö la su dëdo rë
The house is empty, there are no people in it
depressed, sad, anxious, miserable, worried, choked with emotion
Ama diiḳ lob vonġ bayo meḳus in rot
His father died and this made him feel all choked up inside
covetous, desiring, carried away with desire, lustful
Ayo nevu-nevu in ḳupeḳ bë geḳo nġahiseḳë
He was concerned about possessions, wanting to get a great many
Ayo nevu-nevu in bë gevonġ nġaa nipaya
He was constantly thinking about bad things to do
Nġaa nipaya sën ham ayomin nevu-nevu in lo, og su yoh vu rë
The evil things you lust after are not right
Ayo nipaya vu mehöti in vonġ nġaa ti paya
He was unhappy with someone because they did something bad
Devo nos vu kaunsor lob ayo nivesa in rot
They gave food to the councillor and he was very pleased
excited, eager, to be excited, to want, desire, to be anxious to do something
Sayoġ pebip sa bë sa ġevonġ sengii
I'm really excited and want to dance
Sa su ayoġ pebip sa bë sa ġevonġ monë na rë
I don't feel like sending any money
dry-to have one's inside dry, to be choked with dry food
Nyëġ gga sa besayoġ rera raḳ
The sun beat down on me and I became very dry/thirsty
Venë diiḳ lob ayo maggin rot loḳ kwev nġahiseḳë lob ayo sepëp raḳ.
His wife died and he was very sad, but after a number of months he became happy.
hul hul i kamap nogut olsem insait bilong bret o long lewa
Rabönġ ayo sevek ya in neggëp loḳ dob hus ading
The sweetpotato was porous because it was in the ground a long time
The inside of bread is porous/crumbly
Avëh ti ayo sis yi vu sepoh ala in tunġ nos vu sir vahi geyi ma
The woman was jealous because the callers gave food to the others but not to her
porous, full of holes, like a sponge
bel isi, sori i pinis, belhat i pinis
Senër ġaġek sënë vu ham in bë ham kwamin bo sa gayomin geto revuh
I said these things to you so that you would think of me and have peace
Mehöti lëk bayo töḳ in denër bë nalu diiḳ
Someone shook and was amazed because they told him his child had died
sores on the tongue developed by young children still suckling
Hurmahen ayo vo raḳ benilël in rur besu nenum rë
The child developed sores in its moth and refused the breast and wouldn"t drink
Gga nos ti saga bayo vonġin bë ga rot
He ate that food and he really wanted some more
pikinini bilong ol kaikai, diwai, samting
Keden ruharuuh beḳo ayo-ji in gehin na huk mewis
She split the pumpkin and took the seeds to plant in a new garden
Sa hetunġ malaġ raḳ tob saga ayo-peggo rot
I really looked carefully at what was in the cloth
Hil halë ggëp vavunë bë malanġeri, rëḳ ayo-peggo og heljënġ seḳëj pup beneggëp
We see the top/outside is beautiful, but the inside is full of dead mens' bones
Ayööng vonġ om ayo-rasap verup ya
It was cold so his breath was visible
over there beyond you-out of sight/ hidden by the mountain
over here beyond me-out of sight
They came and they went back in here
over there out of sight-beyond the mountain, distant from speaker and hearer both
They passed this place near here and they went way in there
wind-the cold wind blowing down the valley from the headwater or northern end
The wind blew the fire out
He's sick because he got cold
small bag, a small string bag made from pelepeḳ (q.v)
Ġebasu ggipek doḳ na ayur in rëḳ mala nama
Put the knife in the bag so it won't get lost
bilum bilong pikinini insait long bel bilong mama
Hur mahen luu denare loḳ ayur timu
The two babies were in one bag (i.e. they were identical twins)
